title: Insomnia — Neurological Approach
scope: ** Neurological evaluation and management of insomnia in adults with neurological conditions. Focuses on insomnia comorbid with TBI, dementia, MS, Parkinson's disease, chronic pain, epilepsy, and stroke. Covers CBT-I as first-line, pharmacotherapy selection considering neurological comorbidities, and identification of secondary causes. Excludes primary psychiatric insomnia management (though addresses overlap), circadian rhythm disorders as primary diagnosis, and pediatric insomnia.

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Exclude anemia contributing to fatigue and sleep disruption
Electrolyte abnormalities, renal/hepatic function; pre-treatment baseline
Hypothyroidism causes fatigue and hypersomnia; hyperthyroidism causes insomnia and anxiety
Iron deficiency screen; low ferritin (<50 ng/mL) associated with restless legs syndrome causing sleep-onset and maintenance insomnia
Screen for adrenal dysfunction; elevated cortisol causes insomnia; Cushing syndrome; HPA axis dysregulation in chronic insomnia
Exclude stimulant use, substance-related insomnia; caffeine, amphetamines, cocaine

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Deficiency associated with neuropathy, RLS, and sleep disruption
Deficiency contributes to fatigue and neuropsychiatric symptoms
Low testosterone in men associated with fatigue, poor sleep, and reduced sleep quality
Assess dim light melatonin onset (DLMO) in suspected circadian component; low endogenous melatonin in elderly
Diabetes screening; neuropathic pain disrupts sleep; poorly controlled diabetes associated with insomnia
Screen for inflammatory or autoimmune conditions contributing to pain-related insomnia

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Research-level assessment of sleep architecture disruption; cyclic alternating pattern (CAP) rate
If narcolepsy or central hypersomnolence is suspected in the differential
Rare/Specialized.target: Document; supportive of narcolepsy if positive

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If narcolepsy is suspected; rule out central hypersomnolence disorder
Rare/Specialized.target: >200 pg/mL normal; <=110 pg/mL suggests narcolepsy type 1

Essential/First-line.timing: Before any intervention; ongoing during treatment
Essential/First-line.target: Document sleep onset latency, WASO, total sleep time, sleep efficiency; identify patterns and contributing factors

Essential/First-line.timing: Objective assessment of sleep-wake patterns; pre-treatment baseline
Essential/First-line.target: Confirm sleep diary; identify circadian pattern disruption; estimate total sleep time and sleep efficiency
Baseline severity and treatment response; target ISI <8 (remission)
Global sleep quality assessment; PSQI >5 indicates poor sleep quality

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline to screen for excessive daytime sleepiness suggesting comorbid sleep disorder
Essential/First-line.target: ESS <=10 (normal); elevated ESS suggests OSA, narcolepsy, or other hypersomnia

Extended.timing: If comorbid sleep disorder suspected (OSA, PLMD, RBD, nocturnal seizures); NOT for uncomplicated insomnia
Extended.target: Exclude OSA (AHI >5), PLMD (PLMS >15/hr), RBD, nocturnal seizures; document sleep architecture

Extended.timing: If nocturnal seizures or epileptiform activity suspected
Extended.target: Epileptiform discharges; focal slowing; sleep-related epilepsy patterns

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If structural cause suspected (TBI sequelae, hypothalamic lesion, neurodegenerative disease)
Extended.target: Rule out structural lesion, white matter disease, thalamic/hypothalamic pathology

Rare/Specialized.timing: If obstructive sleep apnea is suspected as contributing factor but in-lab PSG not feasible
Rare/Specialized.target: AHI assessment; screen for moderate-severe OSA
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Cannot diagnose central apnea, PLMD, or RBD

Rare/Specialized.item: Advanced circadian rhythm testing (DLMO, core body temperature rhythm)
Rare/Specialized.target: Document phase delay or advance; correlate with actigraphy and sleep diary

Rare/Specialized.timing: If significant cognitive complaints; differentiate insomnia-related cognitive impairment from neurodegenerative process
Rare/Specialized.target: Document attention, memory, processing speed deficits; correlate with sleep quality

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.indication: First-line treatment for chronic insomnia; superior to pharmacotherapy for sustained benefit; effective in insomnia comorbid with neurological conditions

doseOptions.orderSentence: CBT-I (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia) N/A -

dosing.instructions: Individual or group format; 6-8 weekly sessions with trained therapist; includes cognitive restructuring, stimulus control, sleep restriction, relaxation training; digital CBT-I (e.g., Somryst/Pear) if in-person unavailable
dosing.orderSentence: CBT-I (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia) N/A -

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.contraindications: Active untreated psychosis; severe cognitive impairment limiting engagement
Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.monitoring: ISI score; sleep diary; treatment adherence

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.indication: Foundation for all insomnia management; address modifiable behavioral factors

dosing.instructions: Consistent sleep-wake schedule 7 days/week; bedroom dark, cool (65-68F), quiet; remove screens from bedroom; no clock-watching; avoid caffeine after noon; avoid alcohol within 4 hours of bedtime; no naps >20 minutes

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.indication: Break conditioned association between bed/bedroom and wakefulness; re-establish bed as sleep cue

dosing.instructions: Go to bed only when sleepy; if unable to sleep within 20 minutes, leave bedroom and return only when sleepy; use bed only for sleep and intimacy; fixed wake time regardless of sleep obtained

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.contraindications: May be challenging in hospitalized patients or those with mobility limitations
Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.monitoring: Sleep diary; time to sleep onset

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.indication: Increase sleep drive by consolidating sleep; improve sleep efficiency

dosing.instructions: Restrict time in bed to match current total sleep time (minimum 5 hours); increase by 15-30 minutes weekly when sleep efficiency >85%; decrease by 15 minutes if efficiency <80%

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.contraindications: Bipolar disorder (risk of mania); epilepsy (sleep deprivation lowers seizure threshold); use with caution in these populations
Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (FIRST LINE.monitoring: Sleep efficiency; daytime function; seizure frequency in epilepsy patients

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Sleep onset insomnia; preferred in elderly and dementia; circadian rhythm support; minimal side effects and drug interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 1-3 mg 30-60 minutes before desired bedtime; preferred in elderly and dementia patients due to favorable safety profile; may take 2-4 weeks for full effect; extended-release for sleep maintenance

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Insomnia with difficulty falling asleep and/or staying asleep; preferred in dementia-related insomnia; dual orexin receptor antagonist (DORA)

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg within 30 minutes of bedtime; increase to 20 mg if tolerated and needed; effective for sleep onset and maintenance; take only if >=7 hours before planned awakening

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Narcolepsy; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (ketoconazole, itraconazole, clarithromycin); severe hepatic impairment
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Daytime somnolence; sleep paralysis; hypnagogic hallucinations; suicidal ideation (rare)

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Insomnia with difficulty falling asleep and/or staying asleep; dual orexin receptor antagonist; may be better tolerated than suvorexant

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg within 30 minutes of bedtime; increase to 10 mg if needed; take only if >=7 hours before planned awakening; dose adjustment with moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors (max 5 mg)

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Narcolepsy; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors; severe hepatic impairment
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Daytime somnolence; sleep paralysis; headache; nightmares

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Insomnia with comorbid depression or anxiety; commonly used off-label for insomnia; good for sleep maintenance

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg at bedtime; titrate by 25 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 100 mg for insomnia indication; serotonin antagonist/reuptake inhibitor

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Orthostatic hypotension (especially elderly); priapism (rare); next-day sedation; QTc if cardiac risk

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Sleep onset insomnia; melatonin receptor agonist (MT1/MT2); no abuse potential; safe in elderly; no DEA scheduling

dosing.instructions: 8 mg within 30 minutes of bedtime; do not take with or immediately after high-fat meal; no dose titration needed; onset within 30 minutes

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent fluvoxamine (strong CYP1A2 inhibitor); history of angioedema to ramelteon
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Somnolence; dizziness; prolactin levels (with chronic use); reproductive hormone effects

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.indication: Insomnia comorbid with neuropathic pain or restless legs syndrome; dual benefit for sleep and pain/RLS; enhances slow-wave sleep

dosing.instructions: Start 100-300 mg at bedtime; titrate by 100-300 mg every 3-7 days; max 600 mg qHS for insomnia (higher doses for pain/RLS); renal dose adjustment required

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; severe renal impairment (adjust dose); respiratory depression risk with opioids
Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; ataxia; renal function; suicidal ideation

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.indication: Insomnia comorbid with chronic headache, neuropathic pain, or fibromyalgia; tricyclic antidepressant with strong sedating properties

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg at bedtime; increase by 10-25 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 50 mg for insomnia; dual benefit for headache prophylaxis and neuropathic pain

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; recent MI; cardiac conduction disease; narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; AVOID in elderly/dementia (anticholinergic burden, Beers criteria)
Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.monitoring: ECG if cardiac risk or dose >25 mg; anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention); orthostatic hypotension; weight gain; cognitive effects in elderly

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.indication: Insomnia comorbid with poor appetite, weight loss, or depression; most sedating at lower doses (7.5-15 mg) due to predominant antihistaminic effect

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5 mg at bedtime; most sedating at 7.5-15 mg; higher doses (30-45 mg) are less sedating due to increased noradrenergic activity; weight gain is common

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; hepatic impairment (reduce dose); renal impairment (reduce dose)
Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.monitoring: Weight; metabolic panel (lipids, glucose); appetite; agranulocytosis (rare; monitor WBC if fever/infection); sedation

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.indication: Sleep maintenance insomnia; FDA-approved at low doses (3-6 mg) for insomnia; selective histamine H1 antagonist at low dose

dosing.instructions: Start 3 mg within 30 minutes of bedtime; increase to 6 mg if needed; do not take within 3 hours of a meal; FDA-approved for insomnia at these low doses only

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; severe hepatic impairment; use within 3 hours of meal
Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.monitoring: Daytime sedation; nausea; upper respiratory infection (paradoxically common in trials)

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.indication: Insomnia with agitation in dementia or Parkinson's disease; also useful for insomnia with comorbid psychosis or severe anxiety; OFF-LABEL for insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg at bedtime; max 50 mg for insomnia; lowest effective dose; monitor metabolic effects; black box warning for mortality in elderly with dementia-related psychosis

Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.contraindications: Concurrent QT-prolonging drugs; severe hepatic impairment; Lewy body dementia (may worsen motor symptoms; use with extreme caution)
Second-Line / Neurological-Specific Phar.monitoring: Metabolic panel (fasting glucose, lipids, weight) at baseline and q3 months; blood pressure; EPS; tardive dyskinesia; QTc; falls risk

Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.indication: AVOID in elderly, dementia, TBI, fall-risk patients; increased risk of falls, cognitive impairment, delirium, dependence, and respiratory depression

doseOptions.orderSentence: Benzodiazepines (e.g., temazepam, lorazepam, clonazepam) AVOID PO

dosing.instructions: Not recommended as first- or second-line for insomnia in neurological patients; if already prescribed, taper gradually over weeks to months to avoid withdrawal seizures
dosing.orderSentence: Benzodiazepines (e.g., temazepam, lorazepam, clonazepam) AVOID PO

Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.contraindications: Elderly (Beers criteria); dementia; TBI; myasthenia gravis; untreated OSA; history of substance abuse; respiratory insufficiency
Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.monitoring: Cognitive function; falls; respiratory status; dependence; taper if discontinuing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.indication: AVOID in dementia, parasomnia-prone patients, and elderly; risk of complex sleep behaviors (sleepwalking, sleep-driving, sleep-eating)

dosing.instructions: Not recommended in neurological patients due to risk of complex sleep behaviors, falls, and cognitive impairment; if used, lowest dose only (5 mg women, 5-10 mg men)

Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.contraindications: Dementia; history of parasomnias; elderly (Beers criteria); severe hepatic impairment; concurrent CNS depressants
Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.monitoring: Complex sleep behaviors; next-day impairment; falls; cognitive function

Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.indication: AVOID in elderly; high anticholinergic burden; impairs cognition; paradoxical agitation in dementia; tolerance develops rapidly

dosing.instructions: Not recommended for insomnia treatment in neurological patients; anticholinergic effects worsen cognition in dementia, cause urinary retention, and increase delirium risk

Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.contraindications: Elderly (Beers criteria); dementia; narrow-angle glaucoma; BPH/urinary retention; concurrent anticholinergic medications
Medications to AVOID or Use with Extreme.monitoring: Cognitive function; anticholinergic burden; falls; delirium

Referrals & Consults.item: Sleep medicine specialist for formal insomnia assessment, PSG if comorbid sleep disorder suspected, and CBT-I program coordination
Psychology or psychiatry referral for CBT-I delivery; behavioral sleep medicine specialist preferred; digital CBT-I (Somryst/Pear Therapeutics) as alternative when in-person not available
Neurology follow-up for underlying neurological condition management (TBI, dementia, MS, Parkinson's, epilepsy, stroke) as insomnia treatment is more effective when comorbid conditions are optimized
Psychiatry referral if significant comorbid depression, anxiety, or PTSD contributing to insomnia; concurrent treatment improves outcomes for both conditions
Pain management referral if chronic pain is primary driver of sleep disruption; multimodal pain management improves sleep outcomes
Physical/occupational therapy for TBI or stroke patients with insomnia to address activity level, daytime structure, and functional recovery

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Insomnia is a treatable condition; behavioral interventions (CBT-I) are more effective than medications long-term and should be pursued as first-line therapy
Maintain a consistent sleep-wake schedule 7 days per week including weekends; irregular schedules worsen insomnia by disrupting circadian rhythm
Keep a daily sleep diary recording bedtime, estimated sleep onset time, number and duration of nighttime awakenings, final wake time, and subjective sleep quality; bring to all appointments
Take sleep medications at the time prescribed and allow adequate time for sleep (at least 7 hours for most medications) to avoid next-day impairment
Do not increase medication doses without physician guidance; do not combine multiple sleep medications or add alcohol to aid sleep
Seek urgent care if insomnia is accompanied by hallucinations, severe confusion, new neurological symptoms (weakness, numbness, speech difficulty), or suicidal thoughts
Avoid screen use (phone, tablet, computer, TV) for at least 30-60 minutes before bedtime as blue light suppresses melatonin and stimulating content increases arousal
If you cannot fall asleep within 20 minutes, get out of bed and do a quiet, non-stimulating activity in dim light until you feel sleepy, then return to bed (stimulus control)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular moderate exercise (30 minutes daily, 5 days/week) improves sleep quality; avoid vigorous exercise within 4 hours of bedtime as it may increase arousal
Morning bright light exposure (30 minutes within 1 hour of waking) helps entrain circadian rhythm and improve sleep onset; especially important in dementia and TBI patients
Caffeine cutoff by noon; caffeine half-life is 5-7 hours and even afternoon consumption significantly impairs sleep onset and reduces total sleep time
Avoid alcohol as a sleep aid; although it promotes initial sleep onset, alcohol fragments sleep architecture, reduces REM sleep, and worsens insomnia in the second half of the night
Maintain cool bedroom temperature (65-68 degrees F); core body temperature drop facilitates sleep onset
Stress management techniques including progressive muscle relaxation, diaphragmatic breathing, and mindfulness meditation can reduce physiological hyperarousal that perpetuates insomnia
Weight management as obesity is associated with OSA, which commonly coexists with and exacerbates insomnia
Limit daytime naps to 20 minutes maximum before 3:00 PM; longer or later naps reduce homeostatic sleep drive and worsen nighttime insomnia

differential.features: Snoring, witnessed apneas, obesity, morning headaches; may coexist with insomnia (COMISA); EDS more prominent than in pure insomnia
differential.tests: PSG with respiratory scoring; AHI >5 events/hour; STOP-BANG questionnaire

differential.diagnosis: Restless legs syndrome (RLS) / periodic limb movement disorder (PLMD)
differential.features: Urge to move legs worse at rest and evening; sensory discomfort; PLMD causes arousals during sleep; low ferritin common
differential.tests: Clinical history (IRLSSG criteria); serum ferritin; PSG showing PLMS >15/hour

differential.features: Cannot fall asleep until very late (2-6 AM); normal sleep duration once asleep; difficulty waking for early obligations; common in young adults
differential.tests: Actigraphy; sleep diary showing consistent late sleep onset and late wake time; DLMO testing

differential.features: Sleepy in early evening; wakes very early (3-5 AM); common in elderly; total sleep time normal
differential.tests: Actigraphy; sleep diary showing consistently early sleep onset and early wake time

differential.features: Dream enactment behavior; vocalizations during sleep; may cause sleep disruption; strong association with synucleinopathies (Parkinson's, DLB, MSA)
differential.tests: PSG with REM without atonia; video documentation; screen for neurodegenerative disease

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication initiation; common offenders: SSRIs, stimulants, beta-blockers, corticosteroids, theophylline, decongestants, levodopa
differential.tests: Medication review; temporal correlation; trial of dose adjustment or timing change

differential.features: Depressed mood, anhedonia, psychomotor changes; early morning awakening classic; terminal insomnia pattern; insomnia may be presenting symptom
differential.tests: PHQ-9; psychiatric evaluation; insomnia often improves with depression treatment

differential.features: Rumination, worry, hyperarousal at bedtime; sleep onset insomnia predominant; somatic symptoms of anxiety
differential.tests: GAD-7; psychiatric evaluation; cognitive hyperarousal measures

differential.features: Nightmares, hypervigilance, avoidance behaviors; insomnia is core PTSD symptom; often treatment-resistant
differential.tests: PCL-5; trauma history; PSG may show increased REM density and arousals

differential.features: Chronic pain conditions (neuropathy, headache, fibromyalgia, arthritis) causing frequent arousals; pain worse at night; position-dependent
differential.tests: Pain assessment scales; correlate sleep diary with pain diary; treat underlying pain

differential.features: Stereotyped nocturnal events; sleep fragmentation; may not be recognized as seizures; consider in patients with epilepsy and new insomnia
differential.tests: EEG (awake and sleep); video-EEG monitoring; PSG with expanded EEG montage

differential.features: Chronic voluntary sleep restriction due to work, social, or electronic media; resolves with adequate sleep opportunity
differential.tests: Sleep diary and actigraphy showing chronic short sleep time; improvement with sleep extension

evidence.recommendation: CBT-I as first-line treatment for chronic insomnia in adults
European guideline on insomnia diagnosis and treatment; strong recommendation for CBT-I; conditional for pharmacotherapy
Suvorexant (DORA) improves sleep in patients with Alzheimer's disease insomnia without worsening cognition
CBT-I produces sustained improvements in sleep onset latency and wake after sleep onset; meta-analysis of 20 RCTs
AASM clinical practice guideline for pharmacologic treatment of chronic insomnia; recommendations for suvorexant, doxepin, ramelteon, and others
evidence.source: [Sateia et al. J Clin Sleep Med 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27998379/)

evidence.recommendation: CBT-I effective for insomnia following TBI; significant improvements in ISI and sleep diary parameters
evidence.source: [Ouellet et al. J Head Trauma Rehabil 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24495916/)

evidence.recommendation: Lemborexant efficacy and safety for insomnia disorder (SUNRISE 1 and 2 trials)
Low-dose doxepin (3-6 mg) FDA-approved for sleep maintenance insomnia; selective H1 antagonism at low doses
Gabapentin improves sleep in patients with restless legs syndrome and comorbid insomnia
Ramelteon efficacy for sleep onset insomnia; melatonin receptor agonist with no abuse potential
Insomnia as risk factor for cognitive decline and dementia in older adults
AAN practice parameter on insomnia in neurological conditions; behavioral interventions recommended across neurological populations

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; every 4-6 weeks during active treatment; q3 months once stable
monitoring.action: If ISI >=15 despite 6 weeks of treatment: reassess diagnosis, adherence to CBT-I, medication adjustment
Adjust sleep restriction window; reinforce stimulus control; consider medication change

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; focus on specific medication risks
monitoring.action: Dose reduction, medication switch, or discontinuation
Discontinue anticholinergic or sedating medications; reassess sleep medication choice

monitoring.frequency: Each visit if age >65 or neurological condition
monitoring.action: Reduce sedating medications; physical therapy referral; environmental safety evaluation

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3 months: fasting glucose, lipid panel, weight
monitoring.action: Lowest effective dose; consider alternative if metabolic changes; AIMS exam annually

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; orthostatic BP at initiation
monitoring.action: Dose reduction; add fluids/salt; discontinue if priapism occurs (urological emergency)

monitoring.frequency: Baseline ECG if cardiac risk; each visit
monitoring.action: Reduce dose; discontinue if QTc prolonged; switch to non-anticholinergic agent
Psychiatric referral; medication adjustment; intensify behavioral interventions
Reassess treatment plan; evaluate for comorbid sleep disorders; consider PSG

disposition.criteria: Vast majority of insomnia patients; uncomplicated insomnia for CBT-I and/or pharmacotherapy; insomnia comorbid with stable neurological conditions
If comorbid OSA, PLMD, RBD, or nocturnal seizures suspected and outpatient PSG not feasible; schedule PSG night

Severe sleep deprivation with psychosis or delirium; TBI with severe insomnia and neurobehavioral dysregulation; acute neurological condition (stroke, MS relapse, status epilepticus) with significant sleep disruption requiring inpatient management
Not typically applicable for insomnia; consider if severe insomnia-related delirium with agitation requires closer monitoring or if underlying neurological condition warrants ICU care
All patients with insomnia refractory to initial treatment (>=6 weeks CBT-I without improvement); suspected comorbid sleep disorder; need for PSG
Insomnia with new neurological symptoms; suspected neurodegenerative disease; TBI-related insomnia; seizure-related sleep disruption
Insomnia with significant comorbid depression, anxiety, PTSD, or substance use; suicidal ideation; medication management complexity
Every 2-4 weeks during initial CBT-I or medication titration; every 3 months once stable; annually if in long-term remission
